content:
Thanks for the problem.
I feel like the checksum description could be further improved. I first computed it by multiplying by 3 every even position in my result array, keeping every odd position the same, and then had to check an example on an external ressource to realize the correct procedure is the exact opposite. Maybe add an example?
The "INVALID SCAN" string should appear in the I/O section (and can probably be ommited in the description).

Nice problem.
Couldn't you use monospace font areas (between ```) to properly align the code tables?
I also suggest replacing "odd/even digits" by "odd/even indexed digits" in the checksum description.
(NB: The problem got approved precisely when I was writing this comment, I however maintain these suggestions.)

Well done! An interesting exercise. And know that you have tried very hard to explain the complicated conversion procedure.

Would suggest changing this line
"So at this point you are able to reconstruct 12 out of 13 digits."
to "So at this point you are able to reconstruct the last 12 digits."

for the sake of clarity.

and also from
"... is a bit different and has additional empty space from both sides 01010."
to:
"... has a length of 5, having value 01010."

because "empty space" is misleading

I am intentionally avoiding reaching out to search for better explanation about barcode algorithms, relying only on information in this puzzle.
Should let you know that  I am getting lost from the part about L, R and G-codes.
I would suggest you make a real calculation example using your sample data. e.g  in the Left part, 
- the first group is 0001101
- the last group is 0011101
So how these two numbers relates to the given tables, and how it relates to the first digit 4?

Thanks for the comment! 
Instead of overloading the description with some example details I have updated the image sample. It now contains a bit-stream itself and some links between tables with codes to identify the relation.
Hope this would make the barcode encoding idea more vivid for everyone!

Thanks!
I've updated the checksum description.
Regarding the tables alignments I tried but I'm not sure how to do this right. Do you have any examples of such formatting?
One more thing is that current problem description size is really close to the 3000 characters limitation. So, there might not be enough characters left to properly align the tables :(
Anyway it would be good to know how to do such alignment for the future.
Thanks for the comment! I agree even/odd might be a bit confusing and depends on what indexing basis you use (0-based or 1-based). Updated with more clear one.

An example would make it clearer :
4 + (0 * 3) + 0 + (3 * 3) + 9 + (9 * 3) + ... = 110
I tried to add the digits of the multiplication results.
Otherwise it's a really nice puzzle.
Ok thanks (don't bother with the tables then, it's good enough as is).
